questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You need to ensure that a user named user1@contoso.com can call international phone numbers by using Direct Routing.
Which type of policy should you use?

choices.D: From Networks & locations, add the external subnets of the users.
choices.C: Create a new emergency call routing policy that has dynamic emergency calling configured.
choices.B: Create a new emergency calling policy that has external location lookup mode enabled.

discussion.content:
Correct : 
Enable end users to configure their emergency address
Using the Microsoft Teams admin center

 In the left navigation of the Microsoft Teams admin center, go to Voice > Emergency policies.
 Select Add.
 Enter a name for the emergency calling policy, for example, "E911WFH".
 Turn on External location lookup mode.
 Select Apply.

questions.question_text:
You have a Teams Phone deployment.

You need to enable external users to configure their emergency address manually in the Teams client.

What should you do?

HOTSPOT
-

Your company has a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment and the following departments:

• HR
• Marketing

You need to configure Teams to meet the following requirements:

• Only users in the HR department must have spam filtering enabled.
• All outbound PSTN calls must replace the caller ID with the company's auto attendant number.
• Only users in the marketing department must have Inbound calls can be routed to call groups disabled.

What is the minimum number of caller ID policies and calling policies you should configure? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content: Isn't it 1 for Caller ID policies? Even if you use Global (Org-wide default), you need to configure it since default setting of "Replace the caller ID with" is set to "User's number".

discussion.content: I think it's 0 for Call ID because I can take the global, and 2 for Calling is because of two departments.

Selected Answer: BE
B. Grant-CsOnlineVoiceRoutingPolicy
E. Set-CsUserPstnSettings

Explanation:
When enabling users for Direct Routing in Microsoft Teams, after assigning the necessary licenses, you need to configure the users for PSTN (Public Switched Telephone Network) functionality. This involves:

Grant-CsOnlineVoiceRoutingPolicy:

This cmdlet assigns a voice routing policy to the user.
Voice routing policies define how Teams routes calls to the PSTN, including Direct Routing.
Set-CsUserPstnSettings:

This cmdlet configures the user's PSTN settings, such as enabling them for Direct Routing and assigning a phone number.

questions.question_text:
You are enabling users for Direct Routing.

You already assigned licenses to the users.

You need to complete the user setup.

Which two cmdlets should you run? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Answer is correct
Syntax is correct - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/direct-routing-connect-the-sbc#connect-the-sbc-to-the-tenant
5061 is the correct port - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/direct-routing-plan#sip-signaling-ports

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment and a Session Border Controller (SBC) named SBC1.contoso.com.

The SBC has SIP over TLS configured to use the default Microsoft port.

You need to implement Direct Routing from the SBC to Teams Phone.

How should you complete the PowerShell command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//
